SEARCH
Package com.icx.dom.domain.sql

Class SqlDomainController

java.lang.Object
com.icx.common.base.Common
com.icx.dom.domain.DomainController<SqlDomainObject>
com.icx.dom.domain.sql.SqlDomainController
public class SqlDomainController extends DomainController<SqlDomainObject>
Domain controller DomainController for SQL based persistence mechanism. Provides methods to load and store domain objects from and to database.

  • Method Details

    • initialize

      public void initialize(Properties dbProperties, Properties domainProperties, String domainPackageName) throws DomainException, SQLException, ConfigException, SqlDbException
      Register domain classes by given domain package where these classes reside.

      All classes in this package and in any sub package which extend SqlDomainObject class will be registered as domain classes.

      Parameters:
      dbProperties - database connection properties ('dbConnectionString', 'dbUser', 'dbPassword')
      domainProperties - currently only 'dataHorizonPeriod' (e.g. '1h', '30d')
      domainPackageName - name of package where domain classes reside
      Throws:
      DomainException - on error registering domain classes
      ConfigException - on invalid or missing database connection string or unsupported database type
      SQLException - if database connection cannot be established or on SQL errors associating domain classes and database tables
      SqlDbException - on errors associating domain classes and database tables

    • initialize

      @SafeVarargs public final void initialize(Properties dbProperties, Properties domainProperties, Class<? extends SqlDomainObject>... objectDomainClasses) throws DomainException, SQLException, ConfigException, SqlDbException
      Register given object domain classes and base domain classes.

      Provided classes must extend SqlDomainObject class. Only object domain class (highest class in derivation order) must be provided here if derived domain classes exists.

      Inner domain classes and parent domain classes (which are referenced by provided domain classes) will also be registered.

      Parameters:
      dbProperties - database connection properties ('dbConnectionString', 'dbUser', 'dbPassword')
      domainProperties - currently only 'dataHorizonPeriod' (e.g. '1h', '30d')
      objectDomainClasses - list of object domain classes to register
      Throws:
      DomainException - on error registering domain classes
      ConfigException - on invalid or missing database connection string of unsupported database type
      SQLException - if database connection cannot be established or on SQL errors associating domain classes and database tables
      SqlDbException - on errors associating domain classes and database tables

    • allValid

      public final <S extends SqlDomainObject> Set<S> allValid(Class<S> domainClass)
      Retrieve all registered and valid objects of a specific domain class.

      'valid' object means that object could be saved to database before without error.

      Type Parameters:
      S - specific domain object class type
      Parameters:
      domainClass - any domain class (must not be top-level/instantiable)
      Returns:
      set of all objects of given domain class

    • synchronize

      @SafeVarargs public final boolean synchronize(Class<? extends SqlDomainObject>... objectDomainClassesToExclude) throws SQLException, SqlDbException
      Synchronize domain objects controlled by this domain controller instance with the associated database.

      Method first saves potentially existing new objects (objects which are not already stored in database) to database, than loads all currently relevant objects from database and after that unregisters objects which were deleted in database (by another instance) or which fell out of data horizon and which are not referenced by any other object.

      Field values of existing local objects will be overridden by values retrieved from database on load. So, unsaved changes of field values, which were changed in database too, will be discarded and overridden by database values! Warn logs will be written and warnings will be assigned to affected objects in this case. It's recommended to ensure that all local changes are saved before calling synchronize(Class...).

      For data horizon controlled domain classes this method first loads only objects within data horizon DomainAnnotations.UseDataHorizon. But method ensures referential integrity by generally loading all referenced objects even if they are out of data horizon.

      This method is used for initial loading of domain objects from persistence database on startup of domain controller. If there is a single domain controller instance connected to persistence database this method only removes objects which fell out of data horizon from object store on subsequent calls. For single domain controller instance configurations where data horizon control is not active it is sufficient to call this method once at startup.

      Parameters:
      objectDomainClassesToExclude - (optional) object domain classes which objects shall not be loaded from database
      Returns:
      true if any changed or new objects loaded from database, false otherwise
      Throws:
      SQLException - if executed SELECT statement throws SQLException
      SqlDbException - on Java/SQL inconsistencies

    • loadOnly

      public Set<SqlDomainObject> loadOnly(Class<? extends SqlDomainObject> objectDomainClass, String whereClause, int maxCount) throws SQLException, SqlDbException
      Load objects of only one (primary) object domain class (selected by WHERE clause if specified) and also objects directly or indirectly referenced by these primarily loaded objects (to assure referential integrity).

      Note: To provide a WHERE clause one needs knowledge of the relation of Java class/field names and associated SQL table/column names and also knowledge about column types associated to field types. The basic rule for conversion of Java class/field names to SQL table/column names is: CaseFormat.UPPER_CAMEL -> CaseFormat.UPPER_UNDERSCORE. Tables are additionally prefixed by 'DOM_'. E.g.: class name -> table name: Xyz -> 'DOM_Xyz', XYZ -> 'DOM_X_Y_Z' and field name -> column name: xyz -> 'XYZ'. xYz -> 'X_YZ'. If field is a reference field referencing another domain class the correspondent column has appendix '_ID' (object references are realized as foreign key columns referencing unique object id). E.g. class Bike { Manufacturer manufacturer; } -> MANUFACTURER_ID in DOM_BIKE). If field name may be a reserved name in SQL the column name is also prefixed by 'DOM_' (e.g.: date -> 'DOM_DATE', type -> 'DOM_TYPE'). Relation of field and column types generally is database type specific. For building WHERE clause there are following rules: String, Enum and File fields result in appropriate database specific string columns (VARCHAR, NVARCHAR2), number fields (Integer, Long, Double, BigInteger, BigDecimal) result in appropriate database specific number columns (NUMBER, INTEGER, FLOAT, DOUBLE, BIGINT), LocaDate, LocalTime, LocalDateTime fields result in appropriate database specific date/time columns (DATE, TIME, TIMESTAMP, DATETIME) and byte array fields (byte[]) result in appropriate database specific BLOB columns (BLOB, VARBINARY(MAX), LONGBLOB).

      Parameters:
      objectDomainClass - object domain class of primary objects to load
      whereClause - to further shrink amount of loaded objects
      maxCount - maximum number of primary objects to load
      Returns:
      objects loaded from database potentially including referenced objects of other classes than the given object domain class (referential integrity)
      Throws:
      SQLException - on opening database connection or performing SELECT statements
      SqlDbException - if object domain class of any referenced object could not be determined

    • reload

      public <S extends SqlDomainObject> boolean reload(S obj) throws SQLException, SqlDbException
      (Re)load object from database.

      If object is not initially saved or is not registered this method does nothing.

      If direct or indirect parent objects exist which are not yet loaded due to data horizon control these object will be loaded (and instantiated) too.

      Attention: Overrides unsaved changes of this object.

      Type Parameters:
      S - specific domain object class type
      Parameters:
      obj - object to reload from database
      Returns:
      true, if object differs in and therefore was loaded from database, false otherwise
      Throws:
      SQLException - on error establishing database connection
      SqlDbException - if object domain class of any referenced object could not be determined

    • allocateObjectsExclusively

      public <S extends SqlDomainObject> Set<S> allocateObjectsExclusively(Class<S> objectDomainClass, Class<? extends SqlDomainObject> inProgressClass, String whereClause, int maxCount, Consumer<? super S> update) throws SQLException, SqlDbException
      Allocate objects of one domain class for exclusive use by this domain controller instance.

      This method is intended to synchronize access if multiple domain controller instances concurrently operate on the same database.

      Allocated objects must later be released from exclusive use to allow exclusive use by other instances.

      Exclusive allocation of objects is realized by inserting a record in a 'shadow' table for every allocated object with the object id as record id. The UNIQUE constraint for ID ensures, that this can be done only once for one object.

      if 'update' function is given this function will be computed for all exclusively allocated objects and these objects will be saved to database immediately (e.g. o -> o.status = 'processing' -> STATUS = 'processing').

      Objects allocated here are typically already loaded by synchronization.

      Type Parameters:
      S - specific domain object class type
      Parameters:
      objectDomainClass - object domain class of objects to allocate exclusively (non-object domain classes are not allowed here! E.g. if RaceBike extends Bike only RaceBike may be provided)
      inProgressClass - class for shadow records to ensure exclusivity of this operation - e.g. an inner class of given object domain class (or one of it's base classes) named InProgress extending SqlDomainObject
      whereClause - WHERE clause to build SELECT statement for objects to allocate (e.g. STATUS='new') - @see loadOnly(Class, String, int) for details regarding WHERE clause
      maxCount - maximum # of objects to allocate
      update - optional function to compute immediately on allocated objects (or null)
      Returns:
      allocated objects
      Throws:
      SQLException - exceptions thrown establishing connection or on executing SQL SELECT or UPDATE statement
      SqlDbException - on internal errors

    • allocateObjectExclusively

      public <S extends SqlDomainObject> boolean allocateObjectExclusively(S obj, Class<? extends SqlDomainObject> inProgressClass, Consumer<? super S> update) throws SQLException, SqlDbException
      Allocate this object exclusively, compute an update function on this object and save changed object immediately.
      Type Parameters:
      S - specific domain object class type
      Parameters:
      obj - object to allocate exclusively
      inProgressClass - class for shadow records to ensure exclusivity of this operation - e.g. an inner class of given object domain class (or one of it's base classes) named InProgress extending SqlDomainObject
      update - optional function to compute immediately on allocated objects (or null)
      Returns:
      true if this object could be allocated exclusively, false otherwise
      Throws:
      SQLException - exceptions thrown establishing connection or on executing SQL UPDATE statement on saving object
      SqlDbException - on internal errors

    • releaseObject

      public <S extends SqlDomainObject> boolean releaseObject(S obj, Class<? extends SqlDomainObject> inProgressClass, Consumer<? super S> update) throws SQLException, SqlDbException
      Release this object from exclusive use.

      if 'update' function is given this function will be computed for this exclusively allocated objects and this objects will be saved to database immediately (e.g. o -> o.status = 'done' -> STATUS = 'done').

      Type Parameters:
      S - specific domain object class type
      Parameters:
      obj - object to release from exclusive use
      inProgressClass - class for shadow records to ensure exclusivity of this operation - @see allocateObjectExclusively(SqlDomainObject, Class, Consumer)
      update - update function to perform on this object on releasing or null (e.g. o -> o.status = 'done')
      Returns:
      true if object was exclusively allocated before, false otherwise
      Throws:
      SQLException - exceptions thrown establishing connection or on executing SQL UPDATE statement on saving object
      SqlDbException - on internal errors

    • releaseObjects

      public <S extends SqlDomainObject> void releaseObjects(Collection<S> objects, Class<? extends SqlDomainObject> inProgressClass) throws SQLException, SqlDbException
      Convenience method to release multiple exclusively allocated objects from exclusive use.
      Type Parameters:

      Parameters:

      Throws:
      SQLException - exceptions thrown establishing connection or on executing SQL UPDATE statement on saving object
      SqlDbException - on internal errors

    • computeExclusivelyOnObjects

      public <S extends SqlDomainObject> Set<S> computeExclusivelyOnObjects(Class<S> objectDomainClass, Class<? extends SqlDomainObject> inProgressClass, String whereClause, Consumer<? super S> update) throws SQLException, SqlDbException
      Exclusively compute a function on objects of one domain class and save updated objects immediately.

      Works like allocateObjectsExclusively(Class, Class, String, int, Consumer) but releases objects immediately after computing update function. Releasing updated objects (releaseObject(SqlDomainObject, Class, Consumer) is not necessary.

      Type Parameters:
      S - specific domain object class type
      Parameters:
      objectDomainClass - object domain class of objects to allocate exclusively
      inProgressClass - class for shadow records to ensure exclusivity of this operation - @see allocateObjectExclusively(SqlDomainObject, Class, Consumer)
      whereClause - WHERE clause to build SELECT statement for objects to allocate (e.g. STATUS='new') - @see loadOnly(Class, String, int) for details regarding WHERE clause
      update - update function to compute immediately on selected objects (or null) - objects will be saved immediately after computing (e.g. o -> o.status = 'done' -> STATUS = 'done')
      Returns:
      allocated objects
      Throws:
      SQLException - exceptions thrown establishing connection or on executing SQL SELECT or UPDATE statement
      SqlDbException - on internal errors

    • computeExclusivelyOnObject

      public boolean computeExclusivelyOnObject(SqlDomainObject obj, Class<? extends SqlDomainObject> inProgressClass, Consumer<? super SqlDomainObject> update) throws SQLException, SqlDbException
      Allocate this object exclusively, compute an update function on this object, save changed object and releases object immediately from exclusive use.
      Parameters:
      obj - object to compute function for
      inProgressClass - class for shadow records to ensure exclusivity of this operation - @see allocateObjectExclusively(SqlDomainObject, Class, Consumer)
      update - update function to perform on this object or null (e.g. o -> o.count++ -> COUNT = COUNT+1)
      Returns:
      true if this object could be allocated exclusively, false otherwise
      Throws:
      SQLException - exceptions thrown establishing connection or on executing SQL UPDATE statement on saving object
      SqlDbException - on internal errors

    • save

      public boolean save(Connection cn, SqlDomainObject obj) throws SQLException, SqlDbException
      Save object to database on existing database connection.

      If object is 'new', which means it was not stored in database before, appropriate INSERT statement(s) will be performed, otherwise UPDATE statements for changed fields. If there are no differences between object and object representation in database, nothing will be done and false will be returned.

      If (any) domain class of this object has collection or map fields, INSERT and UPDATE statements will also be performed on 'entry' tables associated these fields.

      On SQL exception this exception and the field error(s) recognized will be assigned to the object. In this case object is marked as invalid and will not be found using allValid(Class). If object was already saved, UPDATE will be tried for every column separately to keep impact of failure small. For non-updatable fields original content is restored to ensure data consistency between object and database representation.

      If initial saving - INSERTing object record(s) - fails whole transaction will be ROLLed BACK.

      Parameters:
      cn - database connection
      obj - object to save
      Returns:
      true if object's changes were saved to database, false if object was up-to-date
      Throws:
      SQLException - exception thrown during execution of INSERT or UPDATE statement
      SqlDbException - on internal errors

    • save

      public boolean save(SqlDomainObject obj) throws SQLException, SqlDbException
      Save changed object to database.

      Grabs a database connection form connection pool (ConnectionPool assigned to database connection object SqlDb and gives this connection back after saving object.

      For detailed description see save(Connection, SqlDomainObject).

      Parameters:
      obj - object to save
      Returns:
      true if object's changes were saved to database, false if object was up-to-date and in error cases
      Throws:
      SQLException - exception thrown during establishing database connection or execution of INSERT or UPDATE statement
      SqlDbException - on internal errors

    • saveIncludingChildren

      public void saveIncludingChildren(SqlDomainObject obj) throws SQLException, SqlDbException
      Save object and all direct and indirect children.

      For detailed description of saving one object see save(SqlDomainObject).

      Parameters:
      obj - main object object to save
      Throws:
      SQLException - exception thrown during establishing database connection or execution of INSERT or UPDATE statement
      SqlDbException - on internal errors

    • createAndSave

      public <S extends SqlDomainObject> S createAndSave(Connection cn, Class<S> objectDomainClass, Consumer<S> init) throws SQLException, SqlDbException
      Create, initialize, register and save (save(Connection, SqlDomainObject)) object of domain class using given database connection.

      If provided calls initialization function before object registration to ensure that registered object is also logically initialized.

      Uses default constructor which therefore must be defined explicitly if other constructors are defined!

      If object cannot be saved due to SQL exception on INSERT object will marked as invalid and exception and field error(s) will be assigned to object.

      Type Parameters:
      S - specific domain object class type
      Parameters:
      cn - database connection
      objectDomainClass - top-level domain class of object to create (object domain class)
      init - object initialization function
      Returns:
      newly created domain object
      Throws:
      SqlDbException - on Java/SQL inconsistencies
      SQLException - on error saving object to database

    • createAndSave

      public <S extends SqlDomainObject> S createAndSave(Class<S> objectDomainClass, Consumer<S> init) throws SQLException, SqlDbException
      Create, initialize, register and save object of domain class.

      see createAndSave(Connection, Class, Consumer) and save(SqlDomainObject).

      Type Parameters:
      S - specific domain object class type
      Parameters:
      objectDomainClass - top-level domain class of objects to create (object domain class)
      init - object initialization function
      Returns:
      newly created and saved domain object
      Throws:
      SqlDbException - on Java/SQL inconsistencies
      SQLException - on error saving object to database

    • createAndSaveNoException

      public <S extends SqlDomainObject> S createAndSaveNoException(Class<S> objectDomainClass, Consumer<S> init)
      Create, initialize, register and save object of domain class without throwing exception on error.

      see createAndSave(Connection, Class, Consumer) and save(SqlDomainObject).

      Potentially thrown exception will be logged as well as exception context.

      Type Parameters:
      S - specific domain object class type
      Parameters:
      objectDomainClass - top-level domain class of objects to create (object domain class)
      init - object initialization function
      Returns:
      newly created and saved domain object or null if an exception occurred saving object

    • delete

      public boolean delete(Connection cn, SqlDomainObject obj) throws SQLException, SqlDbException
      Delete object and all referencing (child) objects if possible using existing database connection.

      Deletion of an object means: unregistering object and all direct and indirect child objects from object store, deleting associated records from database tables and removing object from potentially existing accumulations of parent objects.

      Checks if this object and all of the direct and indirect children can be deleted (see DomainObject.canBeDeleted()). No object will be deleted at all if this check fails.

      Note: Database records of old 'data horizon' controlled child objects (which are not registered), will be deleted directly by ON DELETE CASCADE clause (which is automatically defined for FOREIGN KEYs in tables of 'data horizon' controlled domain classes in SQL scripts for database generation).

      Parameters:
      cn - database connection
      obj - object to delete
      Returns:
      true if deletion was successful, false if object or at least one of its direct or indirect children cannot be deleted by can-be-deleted check.
      Throws:
      SQLException - exceptions thrown on executing SQL DELETE statement
      SqlDbException - on internal errors

    • delete

      public boolean delete(SqlDomainObject obj) throws SQLException, SqlDbException
      Delete object and all referencing (child) objects if possible.

      Grabs a database connection form connection pool (ConnectionPool assigned to database connection object SqlDb and gives this connection back after deletion.

      For detailed description of deletion process see delete(Connection, SqlDomainObject).

      Parameters:
      obj - object to delete
      Returns:
      true if deletion was successful, false if object or at least one of its direct or indirect children cannot be deleted by can-be-deleted check.
      Throws:
      SQLException - exceptions thrown establishing connection or on executing SQL DELETE statement
      SqlDbException - on internal errors

    • hasConstraintViolations

      public boolean hasConstraintViolations(SqlDomainObject obj)
      Check for constraint violations of a domain object without involving database.

      Logs violations found and assigns field errors on fields for which constraints are violated.

      Note: column size violation are detected here only for enum fields - values of String fields which are to long for corresponding column will be truncated and a field warning will be generated on saving.

      Parameters:
      obj - object to check
      Returns:
      true if any field constraint is violated, false otherwise
